function.description: Addition
Subtraction
Multiplication
Division
Check if a is greater than or equal to b
Check if a is greater than or equal to b
Check if a is greater than or equal to b
Check if a is greater than or equal to b

Check if a is greater than or equal to b

function.name: and
function.description: Check that both a and b have a value

function.name: or
function.description: Check that at least a or b have a value

function.name: where
function.description: Filter a based on b. Both a and b should be lists.

function.name: where
function.description: Filter a based on b. Both a and b should be lists.

function.name: where
function.description: Filter a based on b. Both a and b should be lists.

function.name: list
function.description: Creates a list of values, just like the kind of thing you get when you use collection properties (or properties inside them).

argument.name: value1
argument.description: First value

argument.name: value2
argument.description: Second value
You can provide as many as you want

function.returnDescription: A list with all values you provided.

function.name: group
function.description: Creates data that mimics the kind of data produced by a group.

argument.name: key1: value1
argument.description: First key-value pair or other group data.

argument.name: key2: value2
argument.description: Second key-value pair or other group data.
You can provide as many as you want

function.name: average
function.description: Calculate the average of all numbers in the list.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The numbers to average

function.name: sum
function.description: Sum all numbers in the list.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The numbers to sum

function.name: min
function.description: Calculate the minimum of all numbers in the list.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The numbers you are trying to find the min of.

function.name: count
function.description: Count how many items in a list actually have a value. Ignores 0, false, "", empty.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The list of values to count.

function.name: first
function.description: Get the first item(s) in a list of values.

argument.name: n
argument.description: How many items to return? Defaults to 1.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The list to return items from.

function.returnDescription: If n is not provided or is 1, the first item. Otherwise, a list of the first n items.

function.name: last
function.description: Get the last item(s) in a list of values.

argument.name: n
argument.description: How many items to return? Defaults to 1.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The list to return items from.

function.returnDescription: If n is not provided or is 1, the last item. Otherwise, a list of the first n items.

function.name: shuffle
function.description: Shuffle the list, i.e. randomize the order of items.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The list to shuffle.

function.returnDescription: A new, shuffled version of the list provided.

function.name: join
function.description: Combine multiple values into one text value, optionally separated by a different text value.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The pieces you want to join

argument.name: glue
argument.description: What to put between the joined pieces of text. Defaults to nothing, i.e. the pieces are just concatenated. Provide `', '` to get a comma-separated list.

function.name: random
function.description: Generate a random number.

argument.name: min
argument.description: Minimum allowed number. Defaults to 0.

argument.name: max
argument.description: Maximum allowed number. Defaults to 100.

argument.name: step
argument.description: Step, i.e. allowed increment. Defaults to 1, which returns integers.

function.name: $now
function.description: Current date and time as number of milliseconds since January 1st, 1970. Note that using `$now` in expressions makes them update automatically as `$now` changes. Mostly useful in conjunction with [date and time functions](?category=datetime) or the `mod` operator.
